newsitem.title: USA: Clinton pick Mondale, Kassebaum to push reform.
newsitem.headline: Clinton pick Mondale, Kassebaum to push reform.

text.p: President Bill Clinton named former Democratic Vice President Walter Mondale and former Kansas Republican Sen. Nancy Kassebaum on Monday to launch a "crusade" to reform the campaign finance laws this year.

Vice President Al Gore, stepping in for Clinton who is recuperating from knee surgery, announced that the president had named Mondale and Kassebaum to lead a public education effort to win passage of stalled reform legislation.

The announcement of the two former politicians comes amid major controversy embroiling Clinton and Gore over allegations their Democratic Party accepted illegal or improper campaign donations for the 1996 election.

Clinton has backed a bipartisan campaign reform plan sponsored in the Senate by Arizona Republican John McCain and Wisconsin Democrat Russ Feingold and a similar bill in the House by a bipartisan group to limit campaign spending and end unregulated "soft money" donations to political parties.
"Today we push our crusade still further," Gore told a White House audience of civic and political leaders calling for an overhaul of the campaign reform laws.
"We are enlisting two of America's leading public citizens, one a Republican, one a Democrat, as spokespeople for the cause of renewing our democracy," said Gore.
"If we don't act quickly, and if we don't act in a truly bipartisan fashion, reform will fail this year as it has year in and year out," said Gore.

Gore noted that Clinton had wanted to be at the event but his surgery on Friday had prevented it. He said that even though Clinton "is having a little trouble walking today he is committed to taking all the strides we need to reform our campaign finance system."

In her acceptance remarks, Kassebaum -- recently married to former Tennessee Reublican Sen. Howard Baker -- said that the drive for campaign reform should not be looked at as "a diversion" from the pending campaign finance investigations -- a remark echoed by Mondale.
She foresaw a tough job ahead in pushing the bipartisan reform measure that has not gained any steam in this Congress.
"It isn't going to be easy to accomplish," she said. "Our goal is to advance bipartisan legislation to create a level playing field (in election campaigns)."
